title: Convex function
summary: In mathematics, a real-valued function is called convex if the line segment between any two points on the graph of the function does not lie below the graph between the two points. Equivalently, a function is convex if its epigraph (the set of points on or above the graph of the function) is a convex set. A twice-differentiable function of a single variable is convex if and only if its second derivative is nonnegative on its entire domain.[1] Well-known examples of convex functions of a single variable include the quadratic function x 2 {\displaystyle x^{2}} and the exponential function e x {\displaystyle e^{x}} .   In simple terms, a convex function refers to a function that is in the shape of a cup ∪ {\displaystyle \cup } , and a concave function is in the shape of a cap ∩ {\displaystyle \cap } .
